ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about derivatives, integrals, series, parametric equations, and polar coordinates.
I learned math and I learned the importance of keeping up with my work throughout the semester.

Taking Math 115 was similar to a rerun of AP Calculus BC, covering content from integration to polar calculus. Math 115 was my only STEM course this semester, and taking it afforded me with an opportunity to develop work and study habits that I could have not found otherwise should I have not taken Math 115. Things from forming study groups and study plans, which this course encouraged through various assignments, provided me with strategies to navigate my academic life beyond mathematics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Ka Ho Wong is the goat.
Too much concepts crammed into one lecture. Hard to learn.

This course is centered around tests, which does not promote the learning process. As much as the explorations, etc. are supposed to help teach the material, many of my classmates who didn't even attend class did fine because tests make up 85% of your grade. A lot needs to be improved for this intro-level maths course.

Strength: There is a lot of support for people who are struggling with math. From office hours to extra help lessons, the team will give you the help you need if you are struggling.

Weaknesses: For a math class, there is no weakness.
Less confusing homework. More peer tutors.

The course is incredibly well-structured, with daily assignments called explorations which previewed course material to problem sets expected at the end of every week. With this rhythm, I was able to craft a solid homework and study schedule that had little to no surprises. My professor did an excellent job of answering questions and covering material with great clarity despite the depth of the content and the natural rapidity of the course. There were instances when our class would fall behind schedule, thus leading to inconsistencies in the assignment of work. However, this would be remedied.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. I think it is poorly designed. But, most STEM majors have to take it so people really have no choice.
If you like math, then this is a great course. If you do not like math and are looking for a QR credit, look elsewhere.
No, I would not. If it is not needed for your major, do not take it because it is taught horribly.

I would recommend this course to a student looking for a solid math course. It could become fast-paced, thus presenting a challenge in addition to the natural complexity of the material. However, it is well-structured and manageable if approached well.
